Color Bracket Glossary:
White
Colors with high lightness and near-zero chroma. These are crisp, clean, beautiful whites that are often used for ceilings, trim, and minimalist interiors. Off-White
Slightly softened whites with a hint of warmth or gray. These are versatile colors and are often used as default wall colors in both traditional and contemporary spaces. Light Near Neutral
Pleasantly light colors that lean toward gray but still retain a faint, discernible amount of their hue parent. Common in Scandinavian or minimalist palettes. Near Neutral
Subdued colors with very low chroma across a wide range of values. These provide a discernible amount of color while maintaining a neutral look and feel. Off-Black
These colors are super dark, with very low value and chroma. They aren’t true black, but they look like it in most settings. With the right lighting or context, their hue parent can peek through. That’s why it’s important to measure and choose a black that aligns with the other colors in your palette. If you’re looking for a true black, check out Sherwin-Williams Tricorn Black or Benjamin Moore’s Black. Low Value
Colors with very low lightness, appearing deep, moody, or dramatic. Often used for accent walls or cabinetry. High Value
Light and airy colors with high lightness levels. Common for ceilings, bathrooms, or any space needing brightness. Low Chroma
Subdued, muted, and grayed-down colors. These are foundational to sophisticated palettes. High Chroma
Bold, energetic colors with maximum saturation. Often used for statement walls or focal accents. Airy
High value with low chroma, conveying openness and softness. Feels fresh and breathable. Barely-There
Extremely light colors with low chroma and minimal hue presence. Almost indistinguishable from white. Bold
High chroma and medium-to-high value, designed to stand out. Great for visual impact and personality. Bright
High chroma and high value. These are attention-getting, happy colors. Dark
Low value colors, regardless of chroma. Evoke a sense of coziness, mystery, or formality. Dramatic
Intense contrast or saturation. These colors feel powerful and commanding. Dusty
Low chroma and mid-range value, often warm. These feel timeworn, vintage, and soft. Faded
Washed-out appearance with low chroma and higher value. Colors appear sun-bleached or aged. Grayed
Colors heavily influenced by gray, giving a softened and toned-down look. Intense
High chroma and lower-to-mid value. They are striking and saturated without being garish. Light
Colors with high value but not necessarily neutral. Soft, uplifting, and open. Muted
Mid-chroma, mid-value colors that are quiet and balanced. Popular in transitional palettes. Pale
High value with moderate chroma. These are tint-like and gentle in appearance. Rich
Moderate to high chroma and mid-to-low value. These colors feel luxurious and full-bodied. Saturated
Colors that are at or near full chroma for their hue. Vivid and unapologetically colorful. Smoky
Dark and soft with hints of gray or brown. Feels moody and vintage. Soft
Low-to-mid chroma with high value. These colors are gentle, nurturing, and calming. Subdued
Similar to muted but more toned-down. Lower chroma with a sophisticated vibe. Toned-Down
Chroma is reduced, value varies. These colors are often created by adding gray to pure hues. Vibrant
Mid-to-high chroma and value. These colors have energy and life without being overbearing. Vivid
Similar to saturated, but slightly higher in perceived brightness. Used to draw attention. Whispery
Extremely light and delicate in hue. Subtle and romantic. Earthy
Low to moderate chroma in the red, orange, or yellow hues. Feels grounded and natural. Calming
Cool, low-chroma hues in the green or blue family. Light to mid-value. Associated with spa or wellness vibes. Cozy
Low-to-mid value warm tones with moderate chroma. They feel intimate and welcoming. Creamy
Hue families between 9–10 YR and up to 7.5 Y, with high value and low-to-moderate chroma. These colors feel buttery and soft, perfect for trim and cabinetry. Dynamic
Contrasting or high chroma with movement and energy. Feels modern and exciting. Ethereal
Extremely high value and very low chroma. These colors feel ghost-like, floating, or dreamy. Eye-Catching
Usually warm or vibrant mid-to-high chroma hues that immediately grab attention. High-Energy
Vivid, saturated colors. Often reds, oranges, or yellows that are physiologically stimulating. Icy
Hue families between 10 BG and 7.5 B. These colors feel cold, sharp, and clean. Often used in crisp modern palettes. Misty
Misty colors are light, low-chroma hues from the cool side of the spectrum — typically in the 120° to 300° range, with high Lightness (L*) and a muted, desaturated appearance. Their softness comes from their reduced chroma and elevated value, which gives them a diffused, veil-like look without leaning stark or icy. Moody
Low value, low-to-mid chroma. These colors create depth and emotion. Relaxing
Low-to-mid chroma and higher value in cool hues. These colors help reduce visual noise. Shadowed
Low value, mid-to-low chroma. Often used for depth in layering. Soothing
Low to mid chroma, high value, often cool hues. Designed to reduce tension and visual intensity. Spa-Like
Soft blues, blue-greens, or blue-violets. Mid to high value and low chroma. Evokes luxury and cleanliness. Tranquil
Blue and blue-green hues with low chroma and high value. These colors evoke calmness and mental clarity. Washed-Out
Very high value and very low chroma. Colors appear to have been diluted or bleached.
